text: [Music]
I'm Michael Franklin I'm a professor of
computer science at UC Berkeley and I'm
director of the ampl the amp lab is a
multi-disciplinary research effort
that's aimed at building scalable
machine learning and data analysis
technology we develop software from very
lowlevel virtualization technology all
the way up through through data analysis
and machine learning algorithms and
applications the amplab is unique for
several reasons probably the most
important reason is the way we approach
the problem of Big Data analysis we're a
cross-disciplinary team that involves
people from many different sub areas of
computer science we have statisticians
and machine learning people we have uh
distributed computing people we have
people who are experts in data
management and databases and all these
people are working together to basic
basically take a new approach to the
data analysis
problem for us to maintain a real world
data platform would just be
prohibitively expensive instead what
we're able to do is use the AWS to
basically scale up our experiments and
try out our new software on on realistic
configurations of hundreds or even
thousands of computers one of the
applications we're working with is a
cancer genomics application like many
areas of science people have realized
that genomics is becoming a big data
problem as genome sequencing technology
continues to improve at a faster and
faster rate there's huge amounts of data
being generated that needs to be
analyzed having access to all this data
and being able to bring in other sources
of data such as clinical information and
other types of public and third party
information raises the possibility of
getting new treatments for cancers the
Holy Grail of much of this work is
actually personalized treat cancer
treatments and so the idea is if you can
sequence a particular cancer tumor and
understand how that tumor is acting in
that person using information from many
other cancers many other people many
other cases you can then look at
prescribing a specific treatment that
can help that particular cancer in the
most effective way this is a big data
problem it's not going to be solved
without parallel computation and Cloud
computation and what we're doing in the
amp lab is leveraging AWS resources to
look at how to uh various algorithms
that use and genomics work at scale how
can we make them run faster and how can
we enable doctors and researchers to be
able to look at more data more quickly
and more
accurately what we're able to do with
AWS is scale out our Solutions across a
number of different applications we
talked about cancer genomics and the
work we're doing there being able to
look at huge amounts of genomics data if
our researchers felt constrained by
their Computing environment they
wouldn't be able to solve the problem
problems that they need to be solving
with AWS and the ability it gives us to
basically bring up Machines of virtually
any size use them for the time we need
them and then turn them back off AWS
gives us the resources to do our work at
that scale and to solve real world
problems
